body.p: Hyphenation testing follows the same automatic test bench setup as for the spellers. The following tests will soon be available (it depends on the availability of the command line hyphenator, which should be ready for download within days):
It is possible that we also can provide hyphenation for OpenOffice, but nothing is decided yet.

section.title: Regression testing
section.p: Regression testing takes as input a set of known problematic words, ie words we have seen have been wrongly hyphenated. These words are sent through the hyphenator, and the result is compared to the expected hyphenation pattern. Finally a test report is generated, which is transformed to Forrest xml, and can be viewed directly in a web browser if Forrest is running.

section.title: Baseform comparison testing
section.p: The point of this test is to compare the hyphenation output from our Polderland hyphenators (InDesign, MS Office) with that of our hyphenating transducer. The input is all baseforms in our lexicon (ie no dynamic compounds), which are then sent through both our hyphenating transducer as well as the command line hyphenator from Polderland.

The result is compared, and all diffs are reported back as bugs in one or the other hyphenator. This test report is also XML, transformed to Forrest XML, which are then directly viewable in your web browser of choice.

section.title: Correct testing
section.p: The input is here a list of (manually) correctly hyphenated words. The words are sent through the hyphenator (with the manually added hyphenation points removed), and the result is compared to the facit. The test report produced will highlight any differences, and give a quality score.

section.title: Hyphenation engine
section.p: As for the spellers, one can test different hyphenator engines. Presently we have only one (soon, that is), the Polderland command line hyphenator.
